text: Caulobacter cells convert from the swimming form to the holdfast form before cell division (see Section 3.5).
However, select species, such as Caulobacter crescentus, undergo elaborate cell differentiation processes.
The cells (approx. 3 µm long) are stained with crystal violet.
Many bacteria faced with environmental stress undergo complex molecular reprogramming that includes changes in cell structure.
Each cell cycle then produces one sessile cell attached to its substrate by a holdfast, while its sister cell swims off in search of another habitat.
Eukaryotic microbes also have highly complex life cycles.
For example, Dictyostelium discoideum is a seemingly unremarkable ameba that grows as separate, independent cells.
Some species, structure, such as the formation of smaller cells or thicker cell surfaces.
